Interpreting Aristotle
4. Later Medieval Views

An influential late medieval approach to future contingents was
included in John Duns Scotus’s theory of metaphysics as a
transcendental science in which the meaning of the univocal notion of
being (ens) was defined as ‘that to which to be is not
repugnant’. Beings in this metaphysical sense are actual things
as well as non-actual possible things, the imagined actuality of which
does not include a contradiction. In the Augustinian tradition
metaphysical possibilities were ultimately based on the divine essence
and represented the ways in which it could be imitated by created
things. According to Scotus, when God as an omniscient being knows all
possibilities, he seemingly does not know them by turning first to his
essence. Possibilities can be known in themselves; in fact, they would
be what they are even if there were no God. Scotus calls the
propositional formulations of pure possibilities logical possibilities
(possibile logicum). These express things and states of
affairs to which it is not repugnant to be. Possibilities as such have
no kind of existence of their own, but are real in the sense that they
form the precondition for everything that is or can be. (For
Scotus’s modal theory, see Vos et al. 1994; Knuuttila
1996; Normore 1996, 2003; Honnefelder 2005.) Scotus takes it as an
obvious fact that there are contingent states of affairs which could
have not been at that very moment of time at which they are
(Ordinatio I.2.1.1–2, 86). This idea of simultaneous
alternatives differed from the traditional view of the necessity of
the present and played and important role in Scotus’s
metaphysics.

All possibilities of being receive intelligible or objective being as
the objects of God’s knowledge. Some of these are included in
God’s providential plan of creation and will receive actual
being. The description of a possible state of affairs at a certain
moment consists of compossible possibilities. Since finite beings are
contingently actual, alternative possibilities are possible with
respect to the time of their actuality, but they are not compossible
with what is actual. According to Scotus, impossibilities are
incompossibilities between possible ingredients, such as
Socrates’s sitting at a certain time and Socrates’s not
sitting at that same time (Lectura I.39.1–5, 62–63;
Ordinatio I.35, 32, 49–51; I.36, 60–1; I.43, 5–7, 14).

Scotus’s modal metaphysics incorporates many ideas similar to
those in the early medieval model developed by Abelard and the
nominales, such as the denial of the necessity of the
present, the distinction between immutability and necessity and the
universal validity of bivalence. Giving up the Thomistic view of the
atemporal presence of the flux of time to God, Scotus explains
God’s knowledge of the truth-value of future contingent
propositions as his knowing which of the possible scenarios will be
actual and which will not (Lectura I.39.1–5, 44). The
definite truth-values of the propositions about possible future events
do not make them necessary, many of these being acts of the will which
as a free cause chooses between alternatives without being determined.
(See Vos et al. 1994; Söder 1999; for some discussions
of Scotus’s view of the free acts of the will, see Dumont 2001;
Normore 2003: 141–145; Langston 2010.) 

Scotus famously attempted to explain the contingency of God’s
eternal choice by distinguishing between the instants of nature in
God’s mind that represent conceptual succession without
separation or interval, for example, the instant of encountering
opposite alternatives and the instant of choosing one of these. Future
contingent propositions founded on God’s eternal choice are
determinately true or false in such a way that they could be
otherwise, independently of whether they are known or not to humans
(Ordinatio I.38.2, 426) These ideas are not found in
Scotus’s early questions on Aristotle’s De
interpretatione that mostly follow Boethius’s views on
future contingents, adding some more elaborated analyses of the
structure of future-tense propositions: they may signify that it is
true now that something will be or signify that something will be
(Opus 2.1.7–9). See the translations and commentary in
Buckner and Zupko 2014. 

Ockham followed Scotus in believing that God’s choice could be
other than it is and that future contingent propositions are true or
false just as Scotus explicated, but he was dissatisfied with
Scotus’s instants explanation, admitting that he did not have
any of his own (Ordinatio d. 38, 578, 581, 584–5; Adams
1987: 1130–1136. Ockham also criticized the view that God knows future free acts
through his own acts of the will as their partial cause, which he,
like many of his contemporaries and later commentators, treated as
Scotus’s position (Ordinatio d. 38, 582–583). This was
Henry of Ghent’s view to which Scotus first subscribed but then
qualified his acceptance. (See Hoenen 1993: 177–179; Söder
1999: 177–183; Schabel 2000: 43–46.) Scotus thought that there
are many contingent propositions known by God that are not simply
chosen but rather permitted such as those about creaturely sins and
other acts of free will (see Frost 2010).

In Scotus’ theory, the synchronic alternatives of a future free
act remain possibilities though not compossibilities at the instant of
that act. He thought that these “logical potencies”
expressed by propositions with non-repugnant terms are not sufficient
for freedom that requires “real potencies” for
alternatives at an instant of time with respect to the same instant
(see Dumont 1995). Ockham did not accept this part of Scotus’s
denial of the necessity of the present, thinking that real capacities
for oppositions are diachronic (Ordinatio d. 38, 581). Opposite
real capacities without temporal succession at an instant were found
problematic by Thomas Wylton, an early critic of Scotus’s ideas
who, while largely following Boethius, put forward some propositional
distinctions similar to those in Scotus’s questions on De
interpretatione. See the edition and comments in Schabel 2011b;
Bornholdt 2017: 116–120.

Ockham believed, as Scotus did, that future contingent propositions
are true or false, that created wills are non-determined free causes,
and that God knows contingent events without their being
simultaneously present to God. (For Ockham’s view, see Adams and
Kretzmann 1983; Normore 1982.) While Scotus preferred to distinguish
God’s eternal knowledge and choice from the temporal order
sharply (Lectura I.39.1–2, n. 28, 85; Ordinatio I.40,
n. 8), Ockham thought that they can be treated as temporally past.
This led him to ask how God’s foreknowledge as something past
and hence seemingly necessary is compatible with the contingency of
future things. Ockham’s answer was that even though God’s
foreknowledge is past, its content is future, and the past truth of
future contingent propositions in God’s immutable but contingent
knowledge does not fall under the necessity of the past (Ordinatio
d. 38, 387–8; Tractatus de praedestinatione
515–516). Many influential late thinkers embraced Ockham’s
view. (See Robert Holkot, Sent. II.2 in Seeing the Future
Clearly, 127, 145–146; Gregory of Rimini, Lectura super I Sententiarum
I.38.2.3 (302–303); Pierre d’Ailly, Quaestiones super libros Sententiarum I.11.3S.) This is also the hallmark of what is called the
Ockhamist view of divine foreknowledge in contemporary philosophical
theology (Zagzebski 1991: 66–97).

Walter Chatton was a contemporary critic of Ockhams’s views
about future contingents and divine knowledge. He also addressed the
theories of Scotus, Wylton, and particularly Peter Auriol, his main
source of inspiration, but mostly avoided formulating his own
position. For an English translation with a commentary of his main
treatise on future contingents, see Bornholdt 2017; see also the
 SEP entry on Walter Chatton.
 Peter Auriol put forward an original revision of the usual
theological position that while future contingent propositions were
neither true nor false in Aristotle, this was not acceptable
concerning divine knowledge. Auriol argued that since these
propositions lack a truth value, even God is aware of the future in an
“indistant” way that does not imply that future contingent
propositions should be treated as true or false. Auriol’s
indistant knowledge abstracts from temporality and simultaneity and is
allegedly compatible with God’s necessary immutability and human
free will (Schabel 2000: 67–123). Auriol’s position
inspired much critical discussion until early sixteenth century. It
came to be regarded as heretical when a Papal commission made a
decision about the theses of Peter de Rivo, who defended a view
similar to that of Auriol. Some of de Rivo’s statements were
officially condemned in 1474 by Pope Sixtus IV (Baudry 1989 (ed.), La querelle des futurs contingents (Louvain 1465–1475). Textes inédits; Schabel 1995–96, 2000:
315–336, 2003a).

English fourteenth-century authors often commented on the
terminological distinctions between determinate and indeterminate
truth and falsity. Ockham characterized all prospective truths,
whether necessary or contingent, as immutable and therefore
determinate, but there were other suggestions as well. Walter Burley,
Richard of Campsall, Arnold of Strelley, and Robert Holkot preferred
to call true propositions about future contingent things as
indeterminately or contingently true. Some commentators have argued
that speaking about this special mode of being true or false was an
attempt to modify bivalence by formulating an idea of many-valued
logic, see Normore 1982, 1993; Gelber 2004: 224–250. For further
texts and studies on late medieval controversies related to
foreknowledge, freedom and future contingents, see Genest 1992;
Schabel 2003a, 2003b, 2007, 2011a, 2011b; Schabel, Friedman, and Balcoyiannopoulou
2001; Rossini and Schabel 2005; Thakkar 2005, 2010. 

A central question for those who gave up the Thomist view was how God
can eternally know the acts of the will which is a free cause? An
influential answer was offerred in the theory of middle knowledge by
Luis de Molina (1535–1600). In addition to the knowledge of all
possibilities and the possibilities which will be actualized in the
providentially chosen history, God has a third kind of knowledge
(scientia media), which comprises the hypothetical truths
about possible beings. In creating the world, God knows what possible
creatures would do in any possible situation (Freddoso 1988).
Molina’s ‘middle knowledge’ theory about
counterfactuals of freedom was actively debated in the sixteenth and
seventeenth century and has remained a living issue in the philosophy
of religion (Dekker 2000).
